story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: Grim Reaper Donald Trump is a deadly enemy of the United KingdomHis decision to risk war with Iran follows a pattern of bad behaviour: threatening punishing import taxes pouring acid rain on a climate change treaty ignoring allies to shift the US embassy in Israel to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor21:45, 13 MAY 2018NewsopinionPresident Donald Trump appears to have other priorities over the UK's&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailInternational outlaw &shyDonald Trump is proving &shyhimself no friend of Britain. By eagerly shooting down the United Kingdom, this one-man rogue state is a serious threat to our peace and prosperity. The Brextremists who once pretended there was the prospect of the greatest trade deal ever no longer kid perhaps even themselves. Tantrum Trump champions not America but Donald First, as we carry on seeing the fallout from a reality TV star hijacking the US Presidency. Offering him tea with the Queen at Windsor and a round of golf with dumb Prince “Airmiles” Andy at Turnberry in July is the modern equivalent of handing Danegeld to an invader. With his unilateral withdrawal from the successful Iran no-nukes deal signed by Britain, Grim Reaper Trump has demonstrated that he does not give a damn. His decision to risk war with Iran follows a pattern of bad behaviour: threatening punishing import taxes pouring acid rain on a climate change treaty ignoring allies to shift the US embassy in Israel to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv.  It is compelling evidence of why Britain is stronger in the European Union than as an isolated target of this loose cannon in America. As the Conservative MEP Daniel Hannan candidly conceded, Brexit is not going as well as he and his fellow quitters had expected. Jobs are at stake and slippery Michael Gove is just the latest Cabinet Minister to humiliate Theresa May as she struggles to negotiate with the Conservative Party let alone with the rest of Europe. Boris Johnson, Trump’s Mini-me in Britain, daily broadcasts the confusion of the Brextremists. If you listen or read the statements and speeches by Emily Thornberry, Johnson’s opposite number on the Labour benches, you will see how she exposes shallow Johnson’s terrifying lack of depth.

title: violent clashes broken out gazaisrael
story: NewsFeared day of bloodshed begins with seven dead, 28 people shot and 10,000 protesting as Donald Trump prepares to launch US embassy in JerusalemSicteen Palestinian demonstrators have been shot dead by Israeli troops and taken to hospital&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAndy Lines12:09, 14 MAY 2018Updated12:24, 14 MAY 2018NewsPalestinians protest over the inauguration of the US embassy following its controversial move to Jerusalem (Image: AFP)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailViolent clashes have already broken out on the Gaza/Israel border ahead of this afternoon's controversial opening of the US embassy in Jerusalem. Medics said that 28 demonstrators have been shot this morning by Israeli army this morning. Israeli forces are reported to have shot and killed at least sixteen Palestinians, Palestinian health officials said. The officials said at least 500 protesters were injured, at least 35 of them by live bullets. The Israel Defence Force said 10,000 people are now involved in violent protests just 400 metres from the border Israeli fighter jets dropped leaflets - in Arabic - over Gaza which read: You are taking part in violent riots which jeopardise your lives. “Hamas is taking advantage of you in order to hide its failures and is threatening you and your family members' well-being.”  Huge protests are planned later in Gaza where 100,000 people are expected to take to the streets. The Israeli Defence Force is preparing for violence and hundreds of troops have been drafted in amid fears protesters will storm the border fence. Amid tight security the Embassy will be formally opened at a ceremony attended by Ivanka Trump and dozens of senior politicians in Jerusalem Donald Trump will address the crowd via a live video link from the White House.  The British, French and German ambassadors and dozens of others are refusing to attend. Ahead of the opening Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu tweeted: The American embassy will open this afternoon in Jerusalem, our nation. What an exciting day for the people of Israel and the State of Israel! Once again, we were dreamers.  Palestinians are also commemorating Nakba Day (Catastrophe Day) which marks the time they were displaced from their homes in 1948.  Mr Trump’s decision to move the embassy has been described by Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas as the “slap of the century”. The US will be the first nation in the world to have its embassy in the disputed city, a move which has sparked anger across the Middle East.  Mr Trump will be represented by his daughter Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner, who arrived in Jerusalem yesterday to a city plastered with tributes to the President.  One massive banner proclaims: God Bless Donald Trump. And hundreds of official signs say “Trump is a friend of Zion” and “Trump make Israel great again”. Buses have had pro-Trump slogans pasted on their sides.

title: 12 day french frazzle heatwave
story: NewsUK weather: 12-day ‘French frazzle’ heatwave on the way with temperatures up to 27C - just in time for royal weddingForecasters say the "weather gods" are smiling on the couple as they get set to tie the knot in Windsor next weekend&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlistair Grant17:17, 13 MAY 2018Updated17:21, 13 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heatwave will arrive on time for Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding - with forecasters saying the weather gods are smiling on the couple. Temperatures in the UK have dipped below average in places this weekend. However, there's a mini-heatwave forecast tomorrow and Tuesday, with highs of up to 25C, before things stay cooler and dry for the rest of next week.  Next weekend, however, forecasters said temperatures will start to pick up again as heat blows in from France. The Met Office predicts the warmth will last through the following week and until the end of May in the South and East, with “very warm” bursts. MeteoGroup predicted highs in the mid-20s or even 27C, close to the 29.1C hottest day of the year on April 19. The North and West are also due warm conditions, although with some showery days.  Met Office forecaster Alex Burkill said: “It looks like turning warmer from the weekend of the royal wedding onwards. “Warm air is expected to come up from the near continent, with warmer-than-average conditions likely for the UK as a whole. “Saturday looks pleasant for the wedding, with dry and bright conditions most likely.” A Met Office forecaster said: “A dry and warm theme is likely to continue into the weekend for much of England and Wales, and through the following week the South and East, though some rain is possible. “The last few days of May could well stay dry and relatively warm in the South and East, with the potential for some very warm spells.”  MeteoGroup forecaster Mario Cuellar said: “Air will probably start coming to the UK from France, with 24C shown on forecast models by May 21 as temperatures increase. “The weather for the royal wedding looks good for people enjoying time outdoors.” American Ms Markle will be relieved after her reported worries about Britain’s weather disrupting her wedding.  The couple will travel in an open-topped carriage if dry, but a covered carriage if wet. The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “It looks like sunblock not brollies for Harry and Meghan’s big day. “And with a warm-up following the wedding, the royal couple could do well going on honeymoon near home.”

title: builder sacked after prank snapchat
story: NewsBuilder sacked after prank Snapchat video goes viral - and he says his bosses have no sense of humourAlun Rees worked for construction company HPC for nearly two years, but his bosses did not see the funny side of his prank video&nbspShareByBronte HowardAnna Slater22:43, 13 MAY 2018NewsAlun Rees was sacked for a humorous Snapchat video in which he took the mickey out of work supervisors (Image: Meida Wales)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A builder lost his job after a prank Snapchat video mocking supervisors went viral.  Alun Rees worked for construction company HPC for nearly two years and was working at an EDF Energy site in Bridgewater, south Wales, building two power stations.  But after posting a series of Snapchat videos on Facebook , with the latest mocking supervisors for being lazy, Mr Rees found himself in a disciplinary hearing and was fired three days later.  Now Mr Rees is not seeing the funny side and has accused his bosses of lacking a sense of humour. “It was a bit of fun, everyone was telling me to keep making them and egging me on because it boosted morale, even the supervisors,” said the former bulldozer operator. “I didn’t mean to upset anybody, I was just having a laugh and everybody on site loved them.”  Mr Rees, who is a dad to one-year-old twin boys and lives in the Rhondda, uploaded four videos on social media in the past year but it wasn’t until the latest one was watched nearly 100,000 times that he was told it was against company policy.  In his latest video, Mr Rees poses as two characters by using different Snapchat filters – a woman with a high pitched voice who is applying for a job in the company and the boss, according to Wales Online .  Throughout the four-and-a-half-minute video, Mr Rees offers the woman, who doesn’t want to work hard or learn anything, three jobs - with the final being a role of the supervisor. “You haven’t got to do anything, you haven’t got to keep your eyes open all day and there’s absolutely no learning involved whatsoever,” Mr Rees says in the video. “You get a Land Rover, lovely nice healthy wage, more than all the operators, and, best of all, you get a shiny blue helmet.” Mr Rees said his colleagues and supervisors encouraged him to make more and supervisors even watched the video in the disciplinary hearing. “I had a friendly warning on the Wednesday and was told to take it down and I did immediately,” he said.

title: dad hunted down paedo uncle
story: News'Dad hunted down my paedo uncle – but he was abusing me too': Defiant survivor tells harrowing tale of her childhoodSurvivor Tanith tells how her father posed as a vigilante attempting to protect his daughter from his paedo brother when in fact he was also abusing her himself the whole time&nbspShareByGemma Aldridge20:09, 12 MAY 2018Updated02:55, 13 MAY 2018NewsTanith McLeod has told how she was abused by her uncle and her father for years while other family members remained in the dark (Image: Steve Bainbridge/Sunday Mirror)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSchoolgirl Tanith McLeod’s family were left reeling with horror when they discovered her uncle had been sexually abusing her. And when he went on the run, the 12-year-old’s dad Glen vowed to hunt down his paedophile brother and bring him to justice. Tanith’s outraged mum and auntie – who had discovered an explicit video of Ian McLeod-McLean assaulting her on his phone – were fiercely behind Glen, seen by family and friends as a heroic vigilante dad on a crusade for his daughter. But the only one not cheering him on was terrified Tanith. Because she was hiding a secret so horrifying she thought no-one would believe it. Her uncle AND her dad had BOTH been abusing her – with assaults starting when she was THREE.  And astonishingly, evil Glen continued to attack his confused and vulnerable daughter while playing the hero, trying to get his brother Ian extradited from Sierra Leone. Now 23, Tanith today waives her right to anonymity to tell her sickening story in the hope of inspiring other children suffering like she did to be brave and speak out about their secret hell. “I want them to know there is life after abuse,” says Tanith. “And you should have the courage to speak out because people will listen to you. Since my dad and uncle were jailed, life has got better. Before that I felt like I could trust no one. “Even after my uncle was found out, I didn’t believe he would be brought to justice. My dad had vowed to find him and bring him home and everyone thought he was protecting me – but I knew he was just as bad as his brother.”  While most people’s first memories are of birthday parties or their first day at school, Tanith can remember being three and already becoming the object of her dad’s unwanted advances. After two years of secret sexual assaults while her mum was out or in bed, the youngster was scared and confused by what was happening to her. She says: “You feel so helpless at the time. You have so many mixed feelings. “To the outside world – and to me a lot of the time – my dad was a good parent. He took me places and made sure I didn’t want for anything and I loved him. “The abuse was just a small evil part of his character – and every time he did it I felt awful, but he was my dad.”  She became so confused and indoctrinated by his depraved acts, that when her uncle began abusing her without his brother’s knowledge, Tanith was already used to being a victim. For years, the two men would take turns to attack her – while to the outside world Tanith seemed to be living the life of any ordinary schoolgirl. Her married parents lived in a nice home in Maidstone, Kent.  Glen was a successful property developer and her family were close with ex-army diving instructor Ian and his wife. Tanith says: “No one suspected a thing. My mum and my auntie would have been horrified if I had ever told them what was going on. “They always wanted me to be safe and happy. And dad and Ian were so careful in the way they carried out the abuse.” It was only when Tanith was 12 and her auntie – who we have agreed not to name – borrowed Ian’s phone in 2008 that the sick web of lies unravelled.  She says: “She was looking at his pictures and she found an explicit video he had made when he was abusing me. She couldn’t believe it. “But it was all there and there was no way anyone could deny it any more. I felt mixed emotions of relief and fear of what would happen next – but also of guilt.” When her dad heard the news his brother was also abusing his daughter, he had a heart attack. Tanith had mixed emotions. “It was really scary because he wasn’t only one of the men who had been doing this to me – he was my dad,” she says. “No one else knew what he had been doing so everyone blamed Uncle Ian for his illness.  I wanted the abuse to stop but I also wanted him to get better because he was my dad. It was very confusing for a child.”  She watched perplexed as her dad became a hero, battling back from illness to travel to Sierra Leone in a bid to bring his brother home.  Everyone around me thought he was doing the right thing but in the background the abuse was still going on,” she says. “I wanted my uncle to go to jail and my dad was trying to make that happen so I didn’t want to come forward about him too in case they both escaped justice.” Two years later in 2010, Ian was extradited after falling ill with malaria while living on the streets of Sierra Leone. Tanith gave evidence via video link at Maidstone Crown Court.  Her uncle pleaded guilty to 19 counts of sexual abuse and was jailed for 12 years. But while the rest of the family breathed a sigh of relief, Tanith hid her dark secret for another year. “I was totally torn about whether to say anything about my dad as I knew what it would do to my family,” she says.  “The abuse was happening less frequently and he had promised me it would stop altogether, so I kept my silence. “Then one day while he was on holiday in Dubai we were talking on Skype and I told him I was going to tell.” Remarkably Tanith, then 14 plucked up the courage to tell a friend and her parents about what was going on.  Her mum – who is also not being named – was then informed and Glen was arrested. Tanith says: “I remember coming home and my mum was just sitting in the house crying – she’d had no idea what had happened and she was completely broken. I felt bad for what it did to my family but I thought that finally the abuse would end and that was a huge relief.”

title: fit active 25 year old
story: News"Fit and active" 25-year-old with Stage 3 brain tumour doesn't qualify for benefits 'because he went travelling for two years'Curt Rimmington's girlfriend Laura Sullivan is providing for both of them while he goes through treatment&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTommy Wathen09:13, 14 MAY 2018Updated11:30, 14 MAY 2018NewsCurt Rimmington, 25, is being supported by his girlfriend Laura Sullivan (Image: Essex Live)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A young man left unable to work due to a Stage 3 brain tumour cannot claim benefits because he went travelling for two years.  Fit and active Curt Rimmington was left shocked when he received the devastating diagnosis after suffering seizures. The 25-year-old, from Colchester, Essex, is being supported by his girlfriend, Laura Sullivan, who is now providing for both of them while he goes through treatment.  Curt's family told Essex Live he tried to claim benefits to help with their expenses, but was stunned when he was told he didn't qualify because he was out of the country for so long.  They have launched a fundraiser to help the young couple through the difficult time.  Curt's younger brother Jack, 19, said: Curt is not entitled to benefits because he was travelling outside of the country for two years even though he had paid national insurance from the age of 16 until he went travelling. He is living with his partner Laura and she is having to provide for both of them and Curt does not receive any support or benefits. The donations that we receive will go towards their general living costs and also additional treatment. Curt had worked in the UK as a vehicle technician from an apprenticeship at the age of 16 until he left the country to travel the world in 2014.  While abroad he worked with bricklayers and in demolition in Sydney, Australia, along with time working on a banana farm in Queensland. Two years later, he returned to Colchester and began working in construction and fencing. Then, in September 2017, he suffered a seizure in his sleep that would later lead towards the discovery of a brain tumour during an MRI scan in hospital. He was initially told that that the tumour was not believed to be cancerous, although several seizures followed in the months after the operation and Curt was then required to undergo open brain surgery in February of this year. Doctors attempted to remove as much of the tumour as possible, but found that the tumour was intertwined with parts of the brain and it limited how much of the tumour could be removed. Tests were done on the samples taken from the brain and it was found to be stage three cancer.

story: NewsOwner of £85,000 Porsche 911 has windscreen full of parking tickets but 'doesn't give a s***'The unnamed owner has been branded 'one of the most ticketed drivers in Britain' by a neighbour after getting numerous fines for not displaying his parking permit&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlex Shipman22:40, 13 MAY 2018Updated23:04, 13 MAY 2018NewsThe unnamed owner has been branded 'one of the most ticketed drivers in Britain' (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe owner of an &pound85,000 Porsche 911 has been hit with &pound400 worth of tickets - even though he's parked in own space The unnamed owner has been branded 'one of the most ticketed drivers in Britain' by a neighbour after getting numerous fines for not displaying his parking permit. The guy is even parked in his own space but not displaying his permit. Madness. Ban private parking companies.

title: i like jekyll hyde three
story: News'I was like Jekyll and Hyde': Mum's traumatic battle with rarely diagnosed condition that actually affects 30% of womenHannah Gilbert said the condition left her brother and sister scared of her and pushed her to the brink of suicide&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTristan CorkHannah Gilbert20:33, 13 MAY 2018Updated10:05, 14 MAY 2018NewsHannah Gilbert said she suddenly transformed into a different person for three weeks a month, from the age of 14 (Image: Gloucestershire Live)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has revealed the horrific condition she has endured her entire life that leaves her 'feeling like Jekyl and Hyde'. Hannah Gilbert said she suddenly transformed into a different person for three weeks every month from the age of 14. She said her brother and sister were scared of her and her behaviour became so bad when she got to 16 that her exasperated family kicked her out. When she moved back a year later, she had an explosive row with her dad and the day after he had a heart and died - something she blamed herself for for years. But Hannah has only been given an official diagnosis for her condition in recent years. Few people know about PMDD - pre-menstrual dysphoric disorder but it affects one in 20 women in Britain. Only one in 50 are diagnosed with the condition despite its ability to ruin lives.  During her heartbreaking battle with the disorder she said she tried to take her life on more than one occasion and she left her husband Sam 'feeling like he's walking on eggshells'. Writing in the Bristol Post , Hannah explained how PMDD has affected her life in her own words...   Writing this, telling my story, has to be one of the hardest things. I want you to know that whatever happens you are not alone, and just because I’m writing this, it doesn’t mean you will have it, but there maybe a possibility, and that’s ok. Pre-menstrual dysphoric disorder is an illness that effects one in 20 women in the UK. Thirty per cent of women in the world have it, 15 per cent of women who suffer, end up self-harming or committing suicide and sadly only two per cent of women get diagnosed. It’s not just about my periods. It is so much more - I wish it was PMS and 'Aunt Flow', out-staying her welcome! It turns out, PMDD sufferers have an anomaly in their gene activity that triggers more sensitivity to estrogen and progesterone, which leads to more intense pre-menstrual symptoms. My symptoms are so severe it stops me having a normal life. There is no worse feeling than living a life, feeling normal, then one day when your body changes and you first start your journey into womanhood, you get robbed. You're robbed of an experience because you are suddenly hit with so many emotions: Intense anger for no reason, depression and extreme anxiety, insomnia and vivid dreams. You feel that you have stepped into the pages of Jekyll and Hyde, that you are now living this life. You become two people: The normal you that pops up for only one week of a month, this person then hides away in the shadows of the other one - that hormonal b***h that you wish would go away, the one you can’t control and don’t understand why all this has happened. I want you to know that I understand, I will be there and I will support you. I spent most of my periods in the school nurse's office, crying in pain from the severe cramps and feeling like a freak. I used to pour my heart out to my mum, saying I hated who I was becoming.  I used to pray to God to end my suffering because the pain was unbearable. My brother and sister were afraid of me, they never knew when I would lose my temper and have an episode. I loathed who I was for three weeks of the month. I went to the doctor's crying for help and my mum came along for support. I was told it was just behavioural and that I would grow out of it. My schooling became effected, but my mum and dad never gave up: They made sure I had tutors to help me, so I could have an education. When I was 16, I was thrown out of my home, I was too dangerous and my moods to unpredictable. Homeless, I moved in with friends. I sofa surfed until a year later, I moved back home. Then on March 16, 2004, I had a huge episode and had a massive argument with my dad. He died the next day from a heart attack and I never got to say sorry, I blamed myself for many years for his death. I was left feeling so dark in myself and that there was something wrong with me and had no hope. I made a few attempts on my life, I self-harmed and I couldn’t stand the weight I would pile on, so I developed an eating disorder. My family and my friends helped me through a lot of this over the years. I never truly spoke about what was going on. How could I say, 'for one week I’m normal and then I feel for three weeks that I really can’t function and have no control'? I’m at my worst a week before and after my period. I just sounded crazy and like I was picking and choosing when I was going to be unwell. For years I went backwards and forwards to my doctor, I was given all diagnoses, no medication was effective and I gave up hope with medical professionals. But she said she felt a huge change when she met her husband Sam. We have been on and off for many years. I’m very lucky as most women I meet who have PMDD have failed relationships. He is very patient, but we do have our problems - our relationship has been pushed a lot because of me. He has always known it wasn’t me, but felt that there is two people in our relationship: He loves me but hates the other one. He has told me he struggles and feels that he is always walking on egg-shells, afraid that whatever he says can trigger me. Over the years, I found ways of coping, throwing myself into work and my hobbies. I loved crafting and needed a creative outlet.  It’s horrible to feel that the people closest to you are the ones that are the worst affected. This was most tested when I had my first child Austin. For so many years I put off having children, mainly fear of birth and fear of me. I was once told labour is like your worst period pain, times that by ten. If my pains were anything to go by, no thank you. Sam also spoke to me about feeling scared of what I might have been like pregnant. The craziest thing happened though when I was pregnant. For the first time in 15 years, I felt normal throughout my pregnancy and for the first six months after having my son. Sam told everyone we meet: 'she hasn’t been crazy, she has been so normal!' It all stopped when I stopped breast-feeding and my periods came back. Trouble really came knocking. My periods didn’t come back like before I had Austin. No, they came back like when I was 14. The depression, feeling so hopeless and manic was scary. Worse, when you are a first time mum and you want to protect your child, but how do you protect them from you? Especially when you are their mum? There is no baby books that can explain me, my baby and my hormones. There was no help. The doctors tried labelling me with postnatal depression. The health visitor was advising me I was depressed. I wanted to pull my hair out and scream. The love I had for my son, I knew there was no way I was depressed, I had so much love for Austin and the connection I had. It broke me to think otherwise. I did question myself and I began to crumble very rapidly. Not being listened to, or people not having the answers because of lack of awareness, is the most detrimental thing when you have PMDD. On one of my darkest days, I found an article about PMDD. It was me, it was how I felt. The only people who listened to me, was Sam, my mum and an extremely supportive manager at work. Through their support I went about getting help. I went back to my doctors, but they dismissed what I was saying and said it was mental health and I was depressed. In the end I paid privately. I saw a wonderful consultant - she knew instantly that it was PMDD and got me on Evorel patches, twice a week. She suggested that I tried the chemical coil, and changed my diet, no more carbs and sugar.

title: its one countrys greatest treasures
story: NewsNHS Heroes Awards winners in full as Prince William leads tributes to doctors, nurses, volunteers, lifesavers and fundraisersCelebrities including Dame Shirley Bassey, Gordon Ramsay, Jamie Oliver, Sir Tom Jones and stars from Coronation Street, Holby City, Casualty and Call the Midwife will be taking part in event brought to you by ITV and the Mirror&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRhian Lubin22:12, 13 MAY 2018Updated08:25, 14 MAY 2018NewsPrince William leads the tributes to the amazing staff of the NHS (Image: Manchester Evening News)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince William will hail the National Health Service as “one of our country’s greatest treasures” on Monday evening. His accolade is a high point of the NHS Heroes Awards, brought to you by ITV and the Mirror to mark the 70th birthday of the institution which has saved so many lives. Celebrities including Michael Sheen, Dame Shirley Bassey, Gordon Ramsay, Jamie Oliver, Sir Tom Jones and stars from Coronation Street, Holby City, Casualty and Call the Midwife will be taking part in a celebration of the awe-inspiring winners at the red carpet bash at the Hilton in London. In a message to be played at the event, guests will hear William say: “The National Health Service is one of our country’s greatest treasures and something we should all be immensely proud of.  “Perhaps the most wonderful thing about the NHS is its people. The skill, care and dedication they provide every day is  truly inspirational.  “I would like to pay tribute to every member of NHS staff and the wonderful volunteers who do so much to support them – we owe you all a huge thank you.” And to make it a really royal occasion for the winners Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, will present a special award.  The amazing winners will collect their awards from an array of stars, led by host Paul O’Grady, who are all eager to celebrate their extraordinary dedication, skill and often life-changing work. Winners drawn from the full range of frontline NHS services across the UK include an inspirational surgeon who saves the lives of knife and gun victims on a daily basis – and saved the first &shystabbing victim of the London Bridge terror attack. There is also a 70-year-old midwife who has been delivering babies in remote and extreme conditions for 50 years, and a pair of doctors who pioneered a non-beating heart &shytransplant procedure that has helped save many lives.  The UK’s first female professor of surgery will also be recognised for her incredible work over decades and for being a role-model to other women. Other winners include a mother who raised more than &pound2million to fund cancer research after losing her son to the disease. And a teenage girl who suffered serious injuries and lost her best friend in the Manchester Arena terror atrocity last year will be honoured for raising thousands of pounds for the specialist unit that saved her life. Time to salute our awe-inspiring winners         Hero Doctor: Trauma surgeon Dr Martin Griffiths, 50, saved the first person stabbed in the London Bridge terror attack last year.   Special Recognition: Brain tumour victim Lewis Hine, 17, of Portsmouth, organises dances for ill teens who, like him, missed their school prom.   Emergency Lifesaver: Medics James Lafferty, Sherridan Best, Caroline Appleby and Vidar Magnusson were first on scene in 2011 when Thusha Kamaleswaran, five, was shot.    Young Fundraising Hero: Freya Lewis, 15, of Manchester, raised &pound40,000 for hospital after surviving Arena bombing.   Hero Nurse: Betty Macintyre, 70, from Oban, has delivered babies for more than 50 years in remote parts of Scotland.   Fundraising Hero: Lynn Lucas, of Newcastle, has raised &pound2million for cancer research.   Mental Health Champs: Paramedics Dan Farnworth and Rich Morton, of Blackpool, created PTSD charity Our Blue Light.

title: madeleine mccanns parents kate gerry
story: NewsMadeleine McCann's parents Kate and Gerry say they will never give up hope in poignant 15th birthday messageMadeleine McCann would have turned 15 on Saturday and her parents, Kate and Gerry, say they will never give up hope that her daughter will come home&nbspShareByTracey KandohlaAnna Slater23:01, 13 MAY 2018Updated23:52, 13 MAY 2018NewsKate McCann recalled the last Christmas she spent with her daughter, when Madeleine was just three years old (Image: PA)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMadeleine McCann's parents have paid a tribute to her on her 15th birthday saying they will never give up. Kate and Gerry McCann wrote: Happy 15th birthday Madeleine! on the official Find Maddie Campaign Facebook page. It was accompanied by a cherished, smiling photo of the missing girl, taken just days before she went missing in 2007. Alongside it is a green and yellow ribbon, symbolising hope. We love you and we're waiting for you, it continued. And we're never going to give up. The photo was uploaded as the Facebook page's cover photo last night and has had over 4,000 likes.  The family are celebrating her birthday with a low key party at home, with family and their twins, 13-year-old Sean and Amelie. Maddie’s great uncle Brian Kennedy said: “It would be lovely to have a celebration one day. We never lose hope.” Maddie's pink bedroom has become a shrine and has remained untouched for 11 years. Mum Kate, an ex-GP, still buys presents for her daughter every year in the hopes that one day she will come home to open them. She buys age-appropriate presents and says a lot of thought goes into her gifts.  She referred to the birthday of her eldest child as a difficult time because that’s when you really feel her absence”. Kate, who is now a part-time medical worker, still spends precious moments each day in Maddie’s bedroom which she reveals has “shocking pink walls and stars on the ceiling” and where her dolls and teddies are on display. Maddie’s birthday falls just nine days after her parents joined an informal prayer gathering in their home village of Rothley, Leicestershire, to mark yet another painful anniversary of her disappearance. During the outdoor service Kate read a poem called The Contradiction to remember Maddie with haunting words: “I trace your steps, I map your face. You’re all I know and so unknown. I cannot hold you, yet I do.”

story: News'Most beautiful royal' Lady Amelia Windsor 'snubbed as she's not invited to Harry and Meghan's wedding'The 22-year-old model, Harry and William's second cousin, has reportedly not been invited to the nuptials at Windsor Castle on Saturday&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNatalie EvansZoe ForseySocial Audience Writer03:33, 14 MAY 2018Updated03:51, 14 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Lady Amelia Windsor, dubbed the 'most beautiful royal', has been snubbed by cousin Prince Harry and not invited to his wedding , it was claimed last night.   The 22-year-old top model will reportedly not be in attendance on Saturday when Harry ties the knot with Meghan Markle at Windsor Castle.  Lady Amelia is the grandaughter of the Queen's cousin Prince Edward, the Duke of Kent, making her 37th in line to the throne. She is Prince William and Harry's second cousin, and the Queen's first cousin, twice removed.   But the Edinburgh student and her older sister Marina, 25, have not been invited to the royal wedding on Saturday, according to The Sun .  The newspaper quotes a friend as saying: They were a little surprised not to be invited as they were looking forward to going. Perhaps Harry just wanted to keep the family invited to a small number or maybe he didn’t want anyone upstaging the bride.  Not many people had heard of the young royal until she appeared on the front cover of Tatler magaine back in 2016, who described her as the most beautiful royal. Ever since the magazine piece Amelia, who is also known as Mel, has been a big name in the industry.

title: national lottery funding peoples projects
story: AdvertorialCharities across country celebrating huge new National Lottery funding boost - find your local winner hereTotal of 57 good causes to receive National Lottery funding through The People's Projects&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Masters00:00, 14 MAY 2018Updated11:36, 14 MAY 2018AdvertorialGlobal Gardens Project team (L-R) Jack Welbourne, Poppy Nicol and Vaida Barzdaite at the Cardiff allotments&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe People's Projects is a partnership between The National Lottery, Big Lottery Fund (who distribute money raised by National Lottery players), STV and ITV to provide the public the chance to have their say in where up to &pound3million of National Lottery funding should go. A community gardens project, a bread-baking initiative to help older people living in care homes and sheltered housing, and a children’s drama group are among those who will benefit this year. Up to &pound3million has been awarded to 57 causes across the UK, making a massive impact on each deserving cause.It follows months of planning for the campaign, which led to a 2 week voting window to decide which which groups and organisations would finally be declared winners out of a shortlist of 95 projects across all 19 regions  In each region, the three projects with the most public votes received grants of up to &pound50,000 to help them continue their work to bring people together, build stronger communities and improve the lives of thousands of people across the country. So to show just how much you are helping incredible community groups make a difference with National Lottery funding, here’s a look at just some of this year’s The People’s Projects winners.... The Trinity Project - Global Gardens Project After winning National Lottery funding of almost &pound50,000 through The People’s Projects, The Trinity Projects, Global Gardens project can’t wait to get planning and see the venture grow. The group promotes intercultural communication at its “football pitch-sized” allotment through gardening, cooking and eating – bringing together refugees, asylum seekers and the wider community. The National Lottery funding will help the group to expand. Co-founder Poppy Nicol says: “It will help us to create a compost toilet, develop an on-site kitchen where we can cook with the food we grow, and appoint an outreach co-ordinator to go to other centres for asylum seekers and refugees to raise awareness of what we do and get more people involved. “It’s really exciting. When we first discovered we had been successful I just thought wow. Now we’re ready to get planning and move forward with what we want to do – we can hold out the hand of friendship, growing and sharing food to bring people together.” Depden Farm - Minds To Mend  A FARM-based project in Suffolk, supporting adults with learning difficulties, acquired brain injuries and mental health problems, is celebrating its National Lottery funding win. The Minds to Mend venture at Depden Care Farm, just outside Bury St Edmunds, will receive &pound49,790 from The People’s Projects to fund a new weekly programme for those recovering from mental health problems and create a brand-new workshop.  Director Tim Freathy, who has headed the charity on his six-acre smallholding for over three years, explains: “They spend time on the farm, tending to the animals and growing crops which we sell, and they take part in team projects like fence building and creating animal enclosures. “National Lottery funding will pay for staff to allow us to open another day a week and help build a new fully accessible workshop to broaden the range of skills DCF offers everyone. “Winning this money will make a massive difference.” Priority Youth Project - Moving Forward

title: party looks over club 18
story: NewsParty looks over for Club 18-30 holidays after 50 years as millennials opt for Instagram-friendly tripsAt its peak, Club 18-30 catered for 100,000 revellers a year at destinations including Malia, Ayia Napa and Magaluf - and spawned the notorious TV series Club Reps&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAmy-Clare Martin21:51, 13 MAY 2018Updated08:59, 14 MAY 2018NewsThomas Cook could be ending their iconic 'sun, sex and party' brand Club 18-30&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThomas Cook could end its iconic “sun, sex and party” Club 18-30 holidays. The tour operator, which has owned the brand since 1998, is “exploring options” that could include selling it as millennials increasingly opt for Instagram-friendly trips over cheap weeks of heavy drinking. At its peak, Club 18-30 catered for 100,000 revellers a year at destinations including Malia, Ayia Napa and Magaluf. Using the slogan “It’s go big or go home and only the legendary will do” it even spawned a cult TV series, ITV’s Club Reps. But a report this month revealed half of 18 to 25-year-olds now say good-looking social media posts are a factor in choosing breaks, in what is dubbed “ego travel”.  Thomas Cook said: “We remain committed to Club 18-30 for summer 2018. “However, we are exploring options for the future of the brand, which could include the possibility of a sale.” The firm plans to focus on its own-brand hotels with a more Insta-friendly business model, including big-name DJs and upmarket cocktails. Club 18-30 trips began in 1965, taking 580 party hunters to Spain’s Costa Brava.

title: prince harry meghan markles wedding
story: NewsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding menu revealed - consisting of British classics made by huge team of 30 chefsChefs will start peeling vegetables in the coming days to make sure everything is in perfect order ahead of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding&nbspShareByVictoria MurphyRoyal correspondent00:01, 14 MAY 2018Updated09:56, 14 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Guests at Harry and Meghan’s wedding will be served seasonal British classics made by a team of 30 staff.  Chefs and their assistants in the Windsor Castle kitchens will start washing and peeling vegetables in the next few days to make sure everything is perfect for the bride and groom. They are due to tie the knot in Windsor on Saturday, and hundreds have been speculating about what the royal couple might feed their 600 guests. Led by the Queen’s chef Mark Flanagan, the team have sourced fresh ingredients from the Home Counties and lands associated with the Queen like Windsor. Mr Flanagan said: The day of the wedding has fallen very kindly for us. “All the British vegetables are just coming into season... and that's been a point of focus for us.  We know the couple wanted us to make sure we used all of the local seasonal produce as much as possible throughout their menu, and this recent good weather is really helping us to achieve that. (For) all their decisions, we purely made suggestions and the couple... they've tasted everything, they've been involved in every detail... “We are using produce off Her Majesty's estates and that features very much. The sweet and savoury canapes are made to be consumed in two bites, while the bowl dishes can be eaten standing up.  Produce like asparagus, peas and tomatoes are in season. The wedding dinner is being staged at Frogmore House by the Prince of Wales, with different caterers responsible for that event for 200 guests. The food is likely to be washed down with champagne and wine from the extensive royal cellars and soft drinks. The head chef would not discuss the dishes in detail but produce like asparagus, peas and tomatoes are in season - providing a wealth of options for the culinary expert who has worked for some of the world's best chefs, like Michel and Albert Roux and Raymond Blanc. In a bid to keep as many ingredients as possible British and local, Mr Flanagan's team have sourced them from the Home Counties and lands associated with the Queen like Windsor.

title: publicity shy chemicals entrepreneur named
story: NewsUK's richest person revealed on Sunday Times Rich List - and you've probably never heard of himJim Ratcliffe, 65, chief executive of Ineos, topped the Sunday Times Rich List with a fortune of £21.05 billion&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTess De La Mare18:04, 13 MAY 2018NewsChemicals entrepreneur Jim Ratcliffe is the UK's wealthiest person (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A publicity shy chemicals entrepreneur is now the richest man in Britain after his wealth leapt &pound15.3 billion in a single year, while Sir Philip Green and Jamie Oliver saw their fortunes slide.   Jim Ratcliffe, 65, chief executive of Ineos, topped the Sunday Times Rich List with a fortune of &pound21.05 billion, leapfrogging his way from 18th place year.  Mr Ratcliffe, whose firm is currently locked in a legal battle with the Scottish government over its moratorium on fracking, emerged in pole position after additional details led to a substantial revaluation of his assets. The Sunday Times has previously described him as publicity shy.  Ineos's director Andy Currie and finance director John Reece shared in his fortunes, joining Ratcliffe in the top 20, taking joint 16th place with fortunes of &pound7 billion each. At second place were the Hinduja brothers, Sri and Gopi, worth &pound20.64 billion.  Their fortune jumped by &pound4.44 billion on 2017, with their India-based car manufacturer Ashok Leyland and Mumbai-based IndusInd Bank having a particularly successful year. British-American industrialist-turned-media mogul Sir Len Blavatnik came in third place with &pound15.26 billion to his name.  The 60-year-old was knighted this year for services to philanthropy - recent donations include &pound50 million to fund the Tate Modern's new wing, and &pound5 million towards the Victoria and Albert Museum's new entrance, as well as funding the Blavatnik School of Government at Oxford University. This year is the 30th anniversary of the Rich List, with the top 20 now worth a combined &pound218.6 billion - increasing their cumulative wealth by &pound33. 5 billion in the last year. Of the 1,000 people on the list, 145 are billionaires. There are now 141 women on the list, with Charlene de Carvalho-Heineken of the brewing dynasty ranked highest at number six.  She and her financier husband Michel de Carvalho - vice chairman of Citigroup - increased their wealth by almost 20% over the past year to &pound11.1 billion. Elsewhere, Arcadia boss Sir Philip Green's fortune took a tumble - his reputation was dragged through the mud following the collapse of BHS after he sold it to a man twice declared bankrupt for just &pound1.  It later emerged that the department store's two pension schemes had a combined shortfall of &pound571 million, risking the future of their 19,000 members and prompting MPs to call Sir Philip to give evidence in front of a parliamentary select committee. Falling sales at his flagship brands Topshop and Miss Selfridge as well as his promise to contribute &pound363 million towards the pension deficit led to Sir Philip's fortune dropping by &pound787 million to &pound2 billion. Celebrity chef Jamie Oliver exited the list completely following a rocky year for his eponymous restaurant empire - it is still undergoing restructuring after racking up debts of more than &pound70 million.  In January the chain announced 12 of its 37 branches were to close. Financier Ernesto Bertarelli and his wife Kirsty saw the biggest decrease in wealth, losing &pound1.48 billion due to falls in Ernesto's pharmaceutical company stakes, the list's author said. The couple are now 11th on the list.  Aristocrat Hugh Grosvenor is still the UK's youngest billionaire at the age of 27 having inherited his fortune and his title - 7th duke of Westminster - following the death of his father two years ago. His property empire includes 300 acres in Mayfair and Belgravia, as well as properties in Oxford, Cheshire, Scotland and Spain. His wealth grew by &pound444 million in the last year to &pound9.96 billion.

title: rapid response nurse car clamped
story: NewsRapid response nurse has car clamped at own hospital and has to pay £60 to get it removedSarah Todd, 31, from Bangor in Northern Ireland, has hit out at hospital car clamping policy that kept her from seeing sick patients&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByShauna Corr21:17, 13 MAY 2018NewsSarah was stunned when she saw her car with a clamp on (Image: Belfast Live)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A nurse had her car clamped when it was parked up in the hospital car park and had to pay &pound60 to get it removed.  Sarah Todd has hit out at hospital car clamping policy that kept her from seeing sick and vulnerable patients.  Sarah is based at Newtownards Hospital in Northern Ireland, but travels throughout the community delivering much-needed medical care and medication, reports Belfast Live .  However, the rapid response nurse found herself unable to go anywhere last Friday after her car was clamped in the hospital car park. And she said it stayed that way from 10am until she paid &pound60 cash to have it removed at around 1.30pm. The community staff nurse admits her parking permit wasn’t on show, but said the PEA parking company worker who turned up to release her mini demanded &pound60 even after she produced it.  I pay &pound15 a month out of my wages to park there, said the Bangor mum. My car was parked in an area where I am allowed to park, but PEA clamped it preventing me from going to see unwell patients. I rang them to come and take if off and they refused until the money was paid. My permit had fallen off when I was driving so it wasn’t visible, but they could have checked the reg with the office,” she added. “The car sits there every day with a ticket on it.  But the 31-year-old said she is not the only hospital worker suffering parking woes at the site. Before her car was clamped last Friday, Sarah said she had already been issued two parking tickets adding, half the hospital has. No one else has been clamped but loads have had tickets, she continued. There’s girls in my office who have to park in other places and their cars are getting damaged. A nurse parked her car and when she went back someone had put dog dirt on the door handles. It’s really bad. Sarah said she would like to see something done about the parking problems at the hospital. And that she would like to have her &pound60 repaid. She added: It says on the sign that it’s &pound40 and I had to pay &pound60, which left me with no money. I rang them and they just didn’t want to know.

title: secret shopper finds out how
story: NewsSecret shopper finds out how much cheaper Aldi really is than rivals for trolley of 33 'everyday' itemsThe discount supermarket swept the board in a price survey this week, coming out cheaper than Asda, Sainsbury's, Tesco, Morrisons and Waitrose&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByIan FletcherSophie Evans10:00, 14 MAY 2018Updated12:13, 14 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet Money Deals updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is known for its low prices and rapid checkout service. And now, a secret shopper has found out just how much cheaper Aldi is than its supermarket rivals - from Asda and Tesco to Waitrose. The discount store swept the board in the High Street supermarket price survey this week, based on a trolley of 33 'everyday' items. Its shopping basket was more than &pound4 cheaper than its nearest rival in the survey - Asda - according to a report published yesterday. The price difference highlights a reason behind the proposed merger between Asda and Sainsbury's, which was announced last month.  The stores have come under growing pressure from many Brits switching to discounters like Aldi and Lidl to save money on their weekly shop. Trade magazine The Grocer carries out a weekly mystery shopping basket survey checking the prices of 33 'everyday' items at the five major supermarket chains - but this week added Aldi as a guest retailer. It found that while Aldi shoppers paid &pound33.14 for their basket of goods, customers at nearest rival Asda paid &pound4.41 more, at &pound37.55. Sainsbury's was ranked next at &pound39.51 - which was &pound6.37 more expensive than Aldi - followed by Tesco, Morrisons and Waitrose.  The Grocer said: Guest retailer Aldi claimed a convincing win over its traditional supermarket rivals this week - and in doing so illustrated one of the key reasons why Asda and Sainsbury's feel the need to merge. Aldi's &pound33.14 total was &pound4.41 cheaper than Asda, helped by offering the lowest price for 27 of the 33 items on our list. Twenty three of these were exclusively cheaper than any of its rivals. This makes Asda 13.3 per cent more expensive and while the gap has closed from 16.5 per cent in January, drastic measures appear to be needed if Asda is to genuinely close the price gap to the discounters.  It added: Hence the Sainsbury's merger - should a post-deal Asda and Sainsbury's live up to their promise to cut many everyday prices by 10 per cent, Asda in particular would start to look a lot more competitive. Sainsbury's, which last week also invested &pound35 million in reducing the price of selected meat and fish products, actually managed to grab third spot this week. Although at &pound39.51 it was &pound6.37 and 19.2 per cent more expensive than Aldi. Tesco was 21.5 per cent more expensive than Aldi at &pound40.70, a difference of &pound7.56. As our shopping list was heavily weighted towards own label, Tesco's Brand Guarantee scheme had little impact on the final standings. Our shopper had 45p taken off her bill at the checkout which still left it &pound7.11 more expensive than Aldi.  Morrisons was over 25 per cent more expensive than Aldi at &pound41.68. In the case of sixth-placed Waitrose the difference was even greater - the &pound14.86 difference on its &pound48 basket makes it 44.8 per cent more expensive. Waitrose also had just two products on deal. This compared with Asda's nine, Aldi's eight, Morrisons' six and four each at Sainsbury's and Tesco.

title: experts convinced finally know what
story: NewsExperts convinced they finally know what happened to doomed flight MH370 - and how pilot made sure jet would never be foundMalaysian Airlines flight MH370 disappeared while flying from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing with 239 people on board&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter23:24, 13 MAY 2018Updated07:42, 14 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Experts are confident the mystery behind MH370 has finally been solved.  A 60 Minutes investigation by Nine News in Australia that aired tonight features a panel of aviation experts working to determine what brought the plane down. Since March 2014 the world has questioned how a Boeing 777 carrying 239 people vanished into thin air en route from Beijing to Kuala Lumpur. Most of the wreckage has never been found but now but now experts say they finally have the answers. Larry Vance, former senior investigator with the Transportation Safety Board of Canada, told the Australian current affairs programme he was confident he knows what happened to the aircraft.  “I think the general public can take comfort in the fact that there is a growing consensus on the plane’s final moments,” he said. The panel believe that the man in the cockpit, Captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah, was responsible. They all agree the pilot “was killing himself” and took the plane to the most remote spot he could so it would “disappear”.  Boeing 777 pilot and instructor Simon Hardy said Captain Zaharie avoided detection of the plane by either Malaysian or Thai military radar by flying along the border, crossing in and out of each nation's airspace. Mr Hard told the programme: “As the aircraft went across Thailand and Malaysia, it runs down the border, which is wiggling underneath, meaning it's going in and out of those two countries, which is where their jurisdictions are.  “So both of the controllers aren't bothered about this mysterious aircraft. Cause it's, 'Oh, it's gone. It's not in our space anymore'. “If you were commissioning me to do this operation and try and make a 777 disappear, I would do exactly the same thing. “As far as I'm concerned, it's very accurate flying because think it did the job and we know, as a fact, that the military did not come and intercept the aircraft.”

title: first picture two brit hostages
story: NewsFirst picture of two Brit hostages kidnapped in Congo as they speak of their relief at being freedBethan Davies and Robert Jesty had been held by armed bandits since Friday after an ambush, during which a ranger was killed&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDavid BurkeRachel Bishop21:39, 13 MAY 2018Updated21:47, 13 MAY 2018NewsBethan Davies and Robert Jesty spent two days in captivity before being freed&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe two British people taken hostage in the Democratic Republic of Congo have been identified after they were freed today. Bethan Davies and Robert Jesty had been held by armed bandits since Friday after an ambush, during which a ranger was killed. A statement released on behalf of the pair said: “We are very relieved that there has been a positive outcome to the kidnapping and are very grateful for the excellent support we have received.  We do not plan to comment further.” The Foreign Office announced earlier today that the pair were freed today, although circumstances around their release have not been revealed. They were kidnapped in the Virunga National Park, which borders Rwanda, in an attack which claimed the life of Rachel Makissa Baraka. Their driver, who has also been freed, was injured during the attack in the famous gorilla park - but his condition is not yet known.  It had earlier been reported that elite SAS soldiers were dispatched to the Democratic Republic of Congo to help efforts to free the hostages. The Britons and the Congolese driver are all receiving support and medical attention, officials in DRC confirmed. In a statement Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said: “I am delighted to announce that two British nationals who were held hostage in the Democratic Republic of Congo have been released. I pay tribute to the DRC authorities and the Congolese Institute for Nature Conservation for their tireless help during this terrible case.    My thoughts are now with the family of Virunga Park ranger Rachel Makissa Baraka who was killed during the kidnapping, and with the injured driver and the released British nationals as they recover from this traumatic incident.” Cosma Wilungula, director general of The Congolese Institute for Nature Conservation, said: “We would like to thank our brave team for ensuring the swift resolution of this incident, and the safe return of the two British nationals.” Park Director Emmanuel de Merode said: “We are deeply saddened by the death of Virunga National Park Ranger Baraka, whose life was tragically cut short whilst protecting the passengers and driver. We wish to extend our deepest condolences to her family and our sincerest gratitude for her bravery and service to Congo. We would like to thank the UK government for their support with this issue.”    The kidnappers had reportedly demanded &pound150,000 in ransom for the pair's release. The circumstances around their release have yet to be clarified. The British ambassador to the Democratic Republic of Congo, John Murton, said: The UK would like to thank the DRC authorities and MONUSCO (The United Nations peace keeping mission) for their assistance in resolving this kidnapping. I would like in particular to praise the courage and commitment shown by the Congolese Institute for Nature Conservation and the Virunga Park authorities over the past three days. My deepest condolences are with the family, friends and colleagues of Rachel Makisa Baraka, the Virunga ranger killed during the kidnapping.  I wish the driver injured during the incident a speedy recovery. The bravery and determination of all the staff of Virunga is vital for the conservation of animals in the park, and the protection of local communities. The 25-year-old ranger was a so-called ‘ecoguard’ providing security on a convoy travelling through the Virunga National Park, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Friday morning. She became the first female ranger in the bloody history of the park to be murdered by bandits. Fellow park rangers confirmed that Rachel was ‘a devoted conservationist who died in the line of duty’. One added: Her only thought would have been the safety and security of visitors to the park who were on the convoy. Virunga National Park - spanning 3,011 miles - is located in DRC’s unstable North Kivu province. It faces multiple threats from rebel groups, local bandits and the self-defence MaiMai militia partly due to its hugely lucrative charcoal industry, for which the trees of the park are the principal raw material. It is also home to one of the world’s largest populations of critically endangered mountain gorillas as well as hundreds of other rare species. In April five rangers aged between 22 and 30 were killed in an attack from a group that officials believe belong to Mai Mai militia. However, the DRC as a whole has faced growing violence recently, with authorities advising Brits avoid numerous areas across the country. The Foreign and Commonwealth Office advice The FCO advise against all travel to the provinces of Kasa&iuml, Kasa&iuml Central, Kasa&iuml Oriental, Haut-Uele, Haut Lomami, Ituri, North Kivu, South Kivu, Maniema and Tanganyika, areas to the west and east of Kananga including Tshikapa and Mwene-Ditu (as shown on the map), and within 50km of the border with the Central African Republic and South Sudan. The FCO advise against all but essential travel to the cities of Goma and Bukavu and to the districts of N’djili and Kimbanseke in Kinshasa. In 2017, there has been an increase in military and police stop-and-search checkpoints in parts of Kinshasa, especially after dark. Since July 2017, there have been increased reports of several towns in the South Kivu province of eastern DRC being attacked by or having come under the control of armed groups.  There are reports of serious clashes between Congolese Armed Forces and militia groups around Uvira in South Kivu Province.  The FCO advise against all travel to this region.

title: it like horror movie three
story: News'It was like a horror movie': Three girls mauled in savage dog attack leaving blood spattered across the groundWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGES The terrified trio were attacked after two dogs went on a rampage yesterday afternoon - a relative said: "I’ve never seen anything like it in my life"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie EvansCillian O'Brien09:13, 14 MAY 2018Updated09:16, 14 MAY 2018NewsDina Collins's arm is now in a sling following the terrifying dog attack (Image: DublinLive)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Three young girls have been hospitalised after being mauled in a savage dog attack that left blood spattered across the ground.   The terrified trio were attacked after two dogs went on a rampage in a housing estate and halting site in north Dublin, Ireland, yesterday.  They were hospitalised with bite injuries after the incident, while blood was left smeared down a fence and splattered on a footpath. It is believed the canines were dumped at the entrance to Avila Park, off the Cappagh Road in Finglas at around 1.30pm yesterday.  Witnesses described a female driver in a black car driving up to Avila Park and letting the pair loose, Dublin Live reports.   The dogs first attacked 12-year-old Katelynn Collins, who desperately attempted to climb a metal fence to escape. Fortunately for the youngster, relative Michael Collins arrived to visit his mother and got out of his van to rescue her. “If I’d been 30 seconds later I think I’d be going to a funeral,” Michael said. “It was like something from a horror movie.” He used his phone to hit the dog and get it off traumatised Katelynn, who fell into his arms. As he put her in his van out of harm's way, one of the dogs left the estate. But the other attacked 11-year-old Dina Collins who suffered three bites to her arm as she tried to protect herself.  Dina recalled: “The big dog came after me and went for my neck, so I put my hands up in the air and he went for my arm. “When he let go of my arm he went for my leg. A man kicked the dog away and I went up to an old woman.” The youngster needed a tetanus shot and antibiotics after the attack. Her arm is now in a sling, but her mum Lisa is relieved it wasn't worse. “There were small children all around there, it could have killed one of the children,” claimed the shocked mother. Katelynn’s sister Helen, 18, also suffered a 'deep' bite to her leg and was treated at Connolly Hospital Blanchardstown. The younger girls were treated at Temple Street Children’s University Hospital.  Police said the trio's injuries were thought to be minor. Katelynn and Helen’s sister, Megan Stokes, was with her family in Temple Street.  She claimed: “Because we are traveller people they think it’s okay to do this.” Families around the site were celebrating First Communions and feared the incident could have been worse if more children were outside. One of the dogs was cornered in a front garden and Gardai and a dog warden removed it. The second dog was still on the loose in the Finglas area yesterday evening. Locals hoped the dog was microchipped so its owners could be traced.

title: it sounded like bomb going
story: News'It sounded like a bomb going off': Asiana jet slices off tail fin of rival airline's plane in runway collisionShocking CCTV footage captured the incident at Istanbul Ataturk Airport&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByScott Feng12:08, 14 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Asiana jet sliced through the tail fin of a rival airline's plane as they collided on the runway. Shocking CCTV footage captured the incident at Istanbul Ataturk Airport, an international hub visited by thousands of British holidaymakers. Footage shows how the Turkish Airlines flight was parked at the gate when it was hit by another plane. The Asiana plane had just started to taxi before take off when it sliced through the tail fin of the parked jet. The wing of the Asiana Airbus A330 can be seen hitting the Turkish Airlines Airbus A321 vertical fin, knocking it clean off.  No passengers are believed to have been injured in the crash but both planes were left requiring extensive repairs. The Asiana Airbus A330, which was flying to the South Korean capital of Seoul when the crash happened, is thought to have been grounded in Istanbul. It is believed the passengers were then put on a different plane to complete their journey.  British tourists Kaarina Barron and her friend Clare Chambers were seated near the back of the stationary Turkish Airline plane when its tail fin was sliced off, reports the Mail Online .  Kaarina, 55, said: It sounded like a bomb going off and the whole plane seemed to tilt over.

title: massive 1000ft fissure opens volcano
story: NewsHawaii volcano spurts out '45kg LAVA BOMBS' after massive 1,000ft fissure opensKilauea volcano has destroyed 37 buildings since it erupted 10 days ago with 2,000 people evacuated on Big Island&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByToby Meyjes10:08, 14 MAY 2018Updated10:12, 14 MAY 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A massive 1,000ft fissure has opened up on Hawaii's Kilauea volcano hurling 45kg 'lava bombs' 100ft into the air and prompting yet more evacuations.  Helicopter footage shows the huge fissure bubbling bursts of rock and magma with an ear-piercing screech after opening up on the side of the 4,000ft-high volcano. Some 37 buildings have been destroyed and nearly 2,000 people ordered to evacuate since the volcano first erupted on May 3. A number of fissures have appeared over the past 10 days but this is among the biggest and stretches to around the quarter of the length of the hillside. Mark Clawson, 64, who lives uphill from the latest fissure and so far is defying an evacuation order, said: It is a near-constant roar akin to a full-throttle 747 interspersed with deafening, earth-shattering explosions that hurtle 100-pound (45-kg) lava bombs 100 feet (30 meters) into the air.  Explosions could be heard in the evacuated Leilani Estates neighborhood of about 1,500 people as steam rose from the cracks. The bulging rim of one fissure wrecked a building, leaving behind torn metal.  In areas where sulphur dioxide emissions are strong, the vegetation has turned brown and leafless trees withered. The U.S. Geological Survey has warned that fissures could erupt throughout the area, and Civil Defense officials on Sunday ordered people living on Halekamahina Road to evacuate and be on the alert for gas emissions and lava spatter.  Meanwhile, other fissures continued to billow smoke over homes on the eastern point of Big Island, the largest of the Hawaiian islands. Even so, some people such as Mr Clawson remain in their homes, confident they will be spared. We are keeping track of lava bombs. One went through the lanai (porch) roof of a neighbor's house, he said. About eight to 10 neighbors had yet to evacuate, he added.
